comments.text:
+Bubs1214 Another person who doesn't know anything about Harold Holts 
disappearance! On Sunday morning 17 December 1967 he and a neighbour, 
Marjorie Gillespie (his mistress), went to Point Nepean to watched the lone 
English yachtsman Sir Alec Rose sail through Port Philip Bay Heads on his 
return journey to England. They were followed in a second car by Alan 
Stewart with Gillespie's daughter Vyner, 20 and her friend, Robert Simpson, 
19. Despite the blustery, muggy conditions Holt wanted to swim at the 
private, exposed ocean at Cheviot Beach, rather than at one of the more 
protected beaches in the bay. Holt changed into his swimming trunks and 
entered the surf shortly after midday. The four witnesses claim they saw 
Holt swimming out to sea when turbulent water suddenly built up around him 
and he disappeared. They called for help and one of Australia's largest 
search and rescue operations was mounted. By nightfall approximately 190 
people were searching for the prime minister. He was officially presumed 
dead on 19th December 1967. The search was scaled down on 22nd December and 
officially terminated on 5 January 1968. Holt's body was never found. 
 Stewart later said "If Mr Holt can take it I had better go in, too." But 
because of the strong undertow Steward did not go out of his depth and 
returned to the beach. So your suggestion that he was killed elsewhere 
and dumped in the ocean is ridiculous!

comments.text:
+DancingPotatoe16 First of all I hated the movie "Jaws" because it 
completely and wrongfully depicted not just the Great White but sharks in 
general. I have been diving with all types of sharks in the Bahamas, the 
coast of California and several other locations that gave me a first 
hand view as to the apex" The  great white, down to reef, lemon, bull, and 
just about every other one in between. This is why I not only and still do 
own and run an auto repair shop for 20+ years but recently finished

comments.text:
+Bubs1214 
No. He just drowned. There's *zero* percent chance that he was eaten by a 
shark. A shark may have attacked him and he died from blood loss, but he 
was *not* eaten. Why?
For one thing, sharks only attack us because we sometimes we resemble 
seals, which is a main food source for sharks.
Secondly, humans taste *terrible* to sharks. The vast majority of the time, 
a shark will bite you to in order to "taste" you as a means of finding out 
what animal you are. Second bites are rare and being eaten is even rarer.
Stop taking Jaws so seriously.

of it were found on a small Pacific island, most of it was dragged off by

They were not doing fine. Huge deforestation caused a total climate change. 
With the population growing almost explosively fast, you need more land to 
farm. So they chopped down the jungle, making it to huge farming lands, 
building new cities and such. Because of the population growth people 
didn't always live along rivers and/or lakes, so when THE drought came 
(lasting years and years), the water supply ran out and the crops died. You 
need to remember that the Mayans were city states, much like ancient 
Greece. They warred alot and with the drought, everything went straight to 
hell basically. They fought over the small resources that were left. Famine 
and chaos. The citys were abandoned and the empire crumbled fast. The mayan 
population are not extinct tho and exist even to this day by the millions, 
they didn't die out or disappeared from the face of the earth. So no, it's 
not a mystery.

Was gonna say Roanoke too. When I was a kid the schoolbooks said it was an 
empty settlement, and all theories said they were simply taken out 
(Killed/kidnapped) by Indians. But it also said the theory was very mixed 
as there was NO evidence of any form of struggle or invasion, i.e. no mass 
amounts of footprints/Hoof prints/cart tracks, no blood, no arrows..

It further said while they did find some tell tale marks that a nearby 
tribe may have been there (like pieces of clothing or trinkets unique to 
said tribe), they were found in such a way that it would more likely point 
to someone SCAPEGOATING said tribe. Another tribe blaming them for the 
atrocity, or another colonial faction blaming the Natives.

The best analogy I can think of would be a cryptic messege claiming to be

were just records, rather than physical evidence of his existence.  Witness 
accounts are not very reliable (also, the earliest records of Jesus of 
Nazarus were years after the events), but we have physical evidence of the 
others you named in the form of places, objects, corpses, and other such 
things.  The biggest critique of Jesus is that the only reason we have to 
believe he existed is because a book written ~100 years after referenced 
events said he existed, and, just because a book says someone exists, it 
doesn't mean he really did.  Otherwise, I'm going to Hogwarts.

The Illuminati (plural of Latin illuminatus, "enlightened") is a name given 
to several groups, both real and fictitious. Historically, the name refers 
to the Bavarian Illuminati, an Enlightenment-era secret society founded on 
May 1, 1776. The society's goals were to oppose superstition, obscurantism, 
religious influence over public life and abuses of state power. "The order 
of the day," they wrote in their general statutes, "is to put an end to the 
machinations of the purveyors of injustice, to control them without 
dominating them."[1] The Illuminati—along with Freemasonry and other secret 
societies—were outlawed through Edict, by the Bavarian ruler, Charles 
Theodore, with the encouragement of the Roman Catholic Church, in 1784, 
1785, 1787 and 1790.[2] In the several years following, the group was 
vilified by conservative and religious critics who claimed that they 
continued underground and were responsible for the French Revolution.

captions.text:
• From Bermuda triangles to Stonehenge lightning
bolts

• We uncover 15 of the most mysterious,
strangest disappearances ever to get extraterrestrial

and speculation enthusiasts riled up
15 - Harold Holt

• 1967, Victoria, Australia, former Prime
Minister Harold Holt an accomplished swimmer

went for a dip at Cheviot Beach near Portsea
• The 59 year old was never seen again

• Speculation ranged from a fake of his
own death to get away from his mistress, to

abduction in a Chinese Submarine, to abduction
by aliens

• But in 2005 it was officially ruled by
a coroner that the cause of death was accidental

drowning, which is a conclusion that doesn't
require a whiteboard and 2 hours to explain

14 - The Bennington Triangle
• The 1950s, a town in Vermont called Bennington,

people disappear in large triangle formation
across the area

• At least 9 disappearances all within 5
years of each other

• Mr Tedford was sleeping on a crowded bus,
14 other passengers, but when it reached its

destination, he was gone though his luggage
and timetable remained

• An 8 year old boy disappears from a farm,
even though the mother was metres away tending

to animals
• For a full list of other disappearances,

refer to the link below this video
• http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bennington_Triangle

13 - The Lost Eskimo Village
• 1930, a local fur trapper near Lake Anjikuni

in Canada frequents a small village in the
snow

• But one day he visits the town only to
discover everyone is missing with a number

of sled dog corpses strewn here and there
• The story goes that it was as if every

human soul had vanished on the spot, and even
one of the graves had been emptied - leading

some to speculate aliens had been involved
• It's turned into an urban legend, and

some have dubbed the town "Roswell North"
12 - Azaria Chamberlain

• 1980, one you should already be familiar
with if you've heard the phrase "The dingo

took my baby"
• For the longest time it was believed the

mother, Lindy Chamberlain, had killed the
baby for personal reasons and blamed a dingo

• She spent 3 years in prison before a piece
of the baby's clothing was found in a dingo's

lair
• And in 2012, it was officially recognised

that a dingo really had eaten the baby, and
a death certificate was printed

11 - Raoul Wallenberg
• The man that disappeared was a hero in

Sweden - a diplomat that single-handedly saved
20,000 Hungarian jews during the Holocaust

• He was last seen arrested on espionage
charges in Budapest after the Soviet Army

showed up, round about 1947
• It's believed he may have been executed

by the Russians but no evidence ever turned
up, and people have spoken of his survival

in Soviet prisons as recent as the 1980s,
though he must be dead by now

10 - The Fort Worth Three
• 1974, three girls all under 18 years of

age went shopping in Fort Worth, Texas
• None of them returned home, despite the

fact they'd finished shopping, and their locked
car was loaded with presents

• The next day, a letter arrived to one
of the girls' families - that they'd taken

off to Houston and would be back in a week,
yet they still never turned up again

• It's been speculated the girls had not
written the letter, and that a mysterious

van had picked them up at Fort Worth, but
this was never confirmed

9 - The Stonehenge Hippies
• 1971, the famous Stonehenge pillars of

England
• Before the stones were officially protected

from the public, a small group of hippies
decided to set up camp in the centre

• At about 2am the next morning, a thunder
storm brewed over the area, bolts striking

trees and even the stones themselves
• Two witnesses a farmer and policeman saw

an intense blue light in Stonehenge, the hippies
screamed and instantly vanished

• It was speculated they were struck by
lightning, but surprisingly their camp was

perfectly intact and there wasn't a single
indication of bodies, blood or death - they

were just gone
8 - USS Cyclops

• 1918, a U.S Navy vessel departs Rio de
Janeiro carrying 11,000 tons of manganese

ore led by Commander George Worley
• En route to Baltimore, it vanishes without

a trace just like 2 other sister ships which
also vanished in the North Atlantic during

World War II carrying similar cargo
• Theories suggest they might've sunk from

excessive weight, or they might've been taken
over by Germans looking to steal the ore

• There's no definitive answer, but the
most popular theory: the Bermuda Triangle

had taken a few more victims
7 - D.B Cooper

• 1971, one of the most famous skyjackings
ever

• Dan Cooper boarded a Northwest Orient
Airlines Flight 305 to Seattle-Tacoma

• 30 minutes into the flight, Cooper told
a flight attendent he had a bomb, that he

wanted $200,000 cash and 4 parachutes
• At Seattle-Tacoma, he let the passenger

hostages go, he got his money and parachutes,
he informed the pilots to fly to Mexico City,

where he jumped from the plane at 10,000 feet
over Southwestern Washington

• Following this, Cooper disappeared forever
with his money, leading to hundreds of books,

films and songs dedicated to Cooper's feat
6 - Owen Parfitt

• 1763, Shepton Mallet, England
• Owen had been paralysed from a stroke,

and one night he was sitting out the front
of his sister's house in view of some workers

across the road
• Later that night, Owen's sister turned

up to move him back into the house, but he
was gone, vanished, nothing but his coat remained

• Investigations were carried out, but nobody
could explain how this immobilised man managed

to disappear into the night
5 - The Jamison Family

• 2009, a recent one, Bobby Jamison, his
wife and 6 year old daughter vanished on a

road in the rural area of Oklahoma
• The story goes they left their truck to

look at some plot of land but never returned
• The dog in the truck was found almost

dead of malnutrition, along with the family's
coats and $32,000 lying under the seat

• Prior to this event, the Jamison's had
reported seeing ghosts in their house, and

speculation included whether they'd gone off
to commit murder-suicide, but nothing was

ever confirmed
• They're still missing to this day

4 - Mary Celeste
• A ghost ship that washed up in the Atlantic

Ocean, 1872
• All 7 of the crewmembers had vanished,

and the life raft was gone leading most to
believe they'd evacuated for one reason or

another
• However, a lot of essential survival gear

had been left behind, the ship's cargo and
valuables untouched which ruled out a pirate

hijacking - so why would they abandon ship?
• The most popular theory is that there

might've been an earthquake, a little water
on deck, people panicked in a hurry, took

the raft and died at sea - but we'll never
be sure

3 - The Crew of the Sarah Joe
• 1979, five men in a little fishing boat

known as the "Sarah Joe"
• This took place in the Hawaiian islands

of Maui, a storm blew up and all men were
lost at sea, which would've been a nice end

to the story had it ended here
• In 1988, a shallow grave was found on

an island 2000 miles away, and in it was buried
the body of one of the fisherman, but then

- who buried him? A lengthy sweep of the island
revealed nothing. What happened to the other

survivors? Nobody knows.
2 - The Nazca Civilisation

• 500 AD, a flourishing society in Peru
along the river valleys Rio Grande de Nazca

and Ica Valley
• Over 250 years this bustling group of

people responsible for beautiful crafts, technologies,
ceramics textiles and geoglyphs was entirely

exterminated
• How? It's a mystery, but clues point to

a massive flood known as El Niño coupled
with their disregard for maintaining forests

that led to soil erosion, no more food and
death

1 - Amelia Earhart
• A famous one, she was an author, teacher,

fashion designer and cigarette spokesperson
• She was basically famous at the time of

her disappearance aboard her plane flying
over the Pacific Ocean in 1937

• At the time she'd been attempting a round-the-world
flight but en-route to Howland Island she

vanished, leading to one of the most intensive
and expensive searches in the history of America

• Nobody ever found her, but she became
a popular subject of science fiction that

she might've been abducted by aliens and whisked
away to wake up far in the future
